newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan OCP, Pakistan's Al Noor sign $220mln deal.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan OCP, Pakistan's Al Noor sign $220mln deal.

text.p: Morocco's phosphates giant Office Cherifien des Phospahtes (OCP) and Pakistan Al-Noor firm signed a $220 million joint-venture deal, the OCP chairman Mourad Cherif said on Monday.

Cherif, who held a news conference at the OCP headquarters in Morocco's financial centre of Casablanca, said: "The $220 deal is an important step towards the consolidation of OCP's presence in Asia...It also opens new prospects for investments in the region."

Under the new agreement, OCP group will build a fertilisers complex near Pakistan's city of Karachi. It will have a capacity of more than 3,300 tonnes of amoniac products and other fertilisers per day.
The fertilsers plant is expected to be operational in 1998.
"Under the agreement terms, OCP will acquire 10 percent of Al Noor capital estimated at $64 million," an OCP manager said.

The Moroccan phosphates conglomerate plans to satisfy Pakistan's demand for phosphoric acid and derivatives estimated at 200,000 tonnes per year or 15 percent of OCP phosphoric acid annual exports, the manager said.
"The OCP-Al Noor partnership will provide Pakistan's market with regular supplies of fertilisers and meet increasing demands of the agricultural sector," he added.
Morocco's main phosphates mines are located in Khouribga and Youssoufia on the Atlantic coast.
